awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF Application: Selective Electrosorption for Boron Removal and Recovery from Seawater
awd_abstract_narration:
Agricultural irrigation is the largest user of water in the United States, accounting for approximately 80 percent of the Nation’s clean water consumption. Seawater desalination is a drought-proof technology that can address growing demands for water in agriculture and other uses. At present, seawater reverse osmosis (SWRO) is the best available commercially available desalination technology. However, the desalinated seawater cannot be used directly in irrigation due to the limited ability to remove boron. This results from limitations on the boron retention capability of commercial SWRO membranes. Boron adversely impacts plant growth and damages apple, citrus, grapes, and other crops when water containing more than 0.3 mg/L of boron is used in irrigation. Thus, commercial SWRO plants must use an additional purification step to reduce boron concentration to acceptable concentrations. This greatly increases the energy consumption and costs of using desalinated water for agriculture. The proposed research will address the inefficiencies associated with boron removal through the development of a novel selective separation technology based on electrosorption. This new technology will be chemical-free, energy efficient, and capable of recovering a high purity boron stream for beneficial uses. Successful completion of this project will advance the development of the next generation of sustainable SWRO plants, with great potential benefit to society. The project will fruther benefit society by providing research training to graduate and undergraduate students at Yale University. Also, the investigator will promote diversity and enhance the involvement of under-represented groups in science and engineering through engagement in Yale's K-12 outreach activities. 

A critical and unresolved challenge in SWRO desalination is to produce a permeate water stream suitable for irrigation without additional and costly purification to remove plant-toxic elements such as boron. The overall goal of this project is to develop an innovative flow-through electrosorption process for boron removal and recovery in seawater desalination. To achieve this goal, the PI proposes to carry out an integrated experimental and modeling project structured around the following tasks: 1) fabrication of an ultra-selective positive electrode (anode) using boron-chelating resins as building blocks; 2) performance testing of the fabricated electrodes for selective boron removal and recovery; 3) elucidation of the mechanisms underlying selective boron electrosorption; 4) assessment of the impact of electrochemical reactions on the long-term stability and boron selectivity of the electrodes; and 5) evaluation and modeling of the energy consumption and boron selectivity of the combined SWRO-electrosorption process. The proposed work would be the first to study boron-selective removal and recovery from seawater using a chemical-free method. The successful completion of this research has potential to transform desalination through the development of a more energy efficient and sustainable boron removal and recovery process from SWRO plants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Boron is a widespread element in seawater, with concentrations ranging from 4-6 ppm. It has also been widely detected in groundwater. Plants are sensitive to boron levels, with both deficiency and excess being harmful. Since irrigation accounts for 70% of global water use, effective boron removal in seawater desalination is crucial. Although boron is a troubling contaminant, it is also a highly versatile and valuable resource, second only to carbon in terms of applications. As both seawater desalination and boron use continue to grow, the need for efficient boron removal and recovery technologies becomes increasingly important.

Despite constituting only 0.01% of the total dissolved solids in seawater, boron removal consumes a disproportionately large amount of energy and chemicals in seawater desalination. To convert boric acid into the more readily removable anion (i.e., borate), the pH of the water must be raised above its pKa of 9.2, typically by adding caustic solutions. However, this high pH environment leads to inorganic scaling on RO membranes due to the natural hardness of seawater. To protect the integrity of RO membranes, boron removal is typically performed in a separate step after nearly all other ions have been removed in a conventional seawater reverse osmosis (SWRO) desalination scheme. Multi-pass RO, though inefficient in terms of energy and chemical use, is still employed in even the largest state-of-the-art desalination facilities, such as the Sorek and Ashkelon plants at Israel, which together produce over 200 million gallons of desalinated water per day. Another widely used boron removal method is boron-selective adsorption. Another widely used method for boron removal is boron-selective adsorption. However, the major shortcomings of both techniques—their high chemical and energy requirements—underscore the urgent need for more sustainable and efficient boron removal technologies.

This project develops an innovative electrosorption process for boron removal and recovery in seawater desalination. Boron selectivity is achieved by functionalizing pristine anodes (commercial carbon cloth) with a series of boron-selective functional groups, which demonstrate a high affinity for borate ions over competing ions (e.g., chloride) in aqueous solutions. Detailed characterization of the functionalized anodes reveals higher surface area, smaller pore size, and a greater number of surface functional groups, compared with the pristine anode. The electrosorption performance of these functionalized anodes is investigated using a custom-built bipolar membrane (BPM) assisted electrosorption device. Results from the performance tests show that the functionalization methods increase boron selectivity over chloride by up to an order of magnitude compared to the pristine anode. This project also evaluates the long-term stability of the functionalized anodes and energy consumption. Molecular dynamics simulations and nuclear magnetic resonance attribute the selective mechanisms to hydrogen bonding and complexation between boron and functional groups. This study addresses persistent inefficiencies in current boron removal technologies and presents an effective approach for the electrosorption of weak acids and bases.

This work has made substantial contributions to the advancement of selective separation technologies. The findings resulted in four publications in high-impact journals, including Journal of the American Chemical Society, Environmental Science & Technology, and Water Research. Furthermore, five presentations were delivered at international conferences, increasing visibility for the innovative methodologies and discoveries made through this project. It also played a key role in training undergraduate and graduate students, along with several postdoctoral researchers, who are now applying these skills in their professional and academic careers.
